columns.text: In this problem, we are required to determine if the management is acting in the shareholders' best interests in a given situation.

Before we begin, let us first define agency problem.

**Agency problem** refers to the tendency of management to put its own needs at the expense of the shareholders.

The goal of the management is to maximize shareholders' wealth. If the management believes that fighting off this hostile bid can improve the profitability of the company and the other bidders will actually pay more than $35 per share, then they are acting in the shareholders' best interests.

However, if the management will not be able to increase the value of the stock beyond the bid price, provided that no other bids will come, then the management is not acting in the shareholders' best interests by fighting for the offer. Managers can lose their jobs if the company is acquired, so they may have an incentive to fight prospective takeovers.
In this task, we need to analyze the given situation.
A hostile bid is a process of attempting to acquire or take control of a business without first receiving the approval of the management or board of directors of the target organization.

The management's primary objective should be to maximize the return on investment for the company's existing shareholders. Management can only fend off this aggressive proposal to acquire the company for $35 per share if they feel they can increase the company's profitability and hence increase its market value over $35, or if they are in a position to receive a superior offer from outside bidders.

Nevertheless, if the present management cannot improve the value of the company above the bid price and there are no alternative offers that are higher, then resisting the offer is not in the shareholders' best interests. Since present managers often lose their positions when a company is bought, inadequately supervised managers have an incentive to oppose corporate takeovers in such instances.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
textbook.title: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
